These identifiers, while seemingly cryptic, are crucial for tracking reservations, ensuring security, and streamlining the travel process. unnormalised: One of the most frequently encountered identifiers is the PNR, or Passenger Name Record. Often referred to as a reservation number or booking reference, the PNR is a unique six-character code generated by airlines or travel agencies when a booking is made. It typically comprises a combination of letters and numbers, such as "ABC12D" or "XYZ987". This PNR serves as a master record containing all the details related to a passenger's itinerary, including flight dates, times, passenger names, contact information, and any special requests (e.g., meal preferences or wheelchair assistance). For example, if Priya Sharma booked a flight from Delhi to Mumbai, her PNR might be something like "DELBOM". Airlines like Air India or IndiGo will generate a unique PNR for each booking.
normalised: One of the most frequently encountered identifiers is the P-N-R, or Passenger Name Record. Often referred to as a reservation number or booking reference, the P-N-R is a unique six-character code generated by airlines or travel agencies when a booking is made. It typically comprises a combination of letters and numbers, such as "A-B-C one two D" or "X-Y-Z nine eight seven". This P-N-R serves as a master record containing all the details related to a passenger's itinerary, including flight dates, times, passenger names, contact information, and any special requests (e.g., meal preferences or wheelchair assistance). For example, if Priya Sharma booked a flight from Delhi to Mumbai, her P-N-R might be something like "D-E-L-B-O-M". Airlines like Air India or IndiGo will generate a unique P-N-R for each booking.

unnormalised: Another crucial identifier is the ticket number. This 13-digit numeric code is uniquely assigned to each individual ticket purchased. It is typically found on the e-ticket confirmation or printed boarding pass. Airlines use the ticket number to track the validity of a ticket, manage seat assignments, and process refunds or changes. An example of a ticket number might be "1234567890123". It’s important to note that each passenger on a single PNR may have their own unique ticket number. Furthermore, sometimes you'll see 'e-ticket ref. no.' along with it on online portals.

unnormalised: Frequent flyer programs also rely on unique identifiers. These membership numbers, such as "AI1234567" for Air India's Flying Returns program or "67890123" for Jet Airways' (now defunct) JetPrivilege program, are assigned to individuals who enroll in loyalty programs. These numbers allow airlines to track accumulated miles, offer exclusive benefits, and personalize the travel experience. Regularly providing your frequent flyer number when booking flights ensures that you receive the miles and privileges you're entitled to.

unnormalised: For train travel in India, the IRCTC (Indian Railway Catering and Tourism Corporation) uses a 10-digit PNR. Similar to airline PNRs, this number, for example "1234567890", allows passengers to check their reservation status, track train schedules, and access platform information. You can typically find your IRCTC PNR on your e-ticket or SMS confirmation.

unnormalised: Understanding these various travel and ticketing identifiers empowers travelers to navigate the booking process more confidently, resolve any potential issues efficiently, and ensure a smooth and hassle-free journey.
